qas.question: What has had major effects on the transmission of diarrheal diseases?
How much does hand washing reduce the chances of disease?
Why do developing countries not wash their hands as much as other countries?

answers.text: access to soap and water is limited

qas.question: What is a solution to help this problem?

answers.text: implementation of educational programs that encourage sanitary behaviours

qas.question: What has a profound effect in developed countries?
By what percentage do educational programs reduce the chance of disease?

plausible_answers.text: implementation of educational programs that encourage sanitary behaviours.

qas.question: What is a solution to poverty?

plausible_answers.text: in all parts of the world

qas.question: Where is education integral to prevent disease?
What is a challenge to reduce disease in less developed countries?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>Basic sanitation techniques<b4_0/><a0_0/> can have a profound effect on the transmission of diarrheal disease. The implementation of hand washing using soap and water, for example, has been experimentally shown to reduce the incidence of disease by <a1_0><b5_0>approximately 42–48%<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Hand washing in developing countries, however, is compromised by poverty as acknowledged by the CDC: "Handwashing is integral to disease prevention <b7_0>in all parts of the world<b7_0/>; however, <a2_0>access to soap and water is limited<a2_0/> in a number of less developed countries. This <b8_0>lack of access<b8_0/> is one of many challenges to proper hygiene in less developed countries." Solutions to this barrier require the <a3_0><b6_0>implementation of educational programs that encourage sanitary behaviours<a3_0/>.
